statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: UNLV 73, California 72
article.story: BERKELEY, Calif. (AP) -- Andy Hannan thought he might be open to take the deciding shot, because he's not someone most teams would suspect. The seldom-used senior hit an 18-foot jumper with 0.4 seconds left to lift UNLV to a thrilling 73-72 victory over California on Wednesday night. "I was dead open," Hannan said. "I released it and I'm thinking to myself, 'This better go in!' I knew I had to stay ready." Marquise Kately's jumper in the paint with 13.9 seconds remaining put Cal ahead, and the Golden Bears seemed to have a victory in hand when UNLV's Jerel Blassingame was called for a charge with 7.7 seconds to play. But after Cal inbounded the ball under the Runnin' Rebels' basket, Richard Midgley traveled and gave UNLV the ball back with 2.7 seconds to go and Hannan came up huge. He was 4-for-25 for his career before swishing the winning shot. Romel Beck scored 21 points for UNLV (2-1), while Odartey Blankson added 16 points and five rebounds. Rod Benson scored a career-high 22 points and added eight rebounds for the Bears (3-2), who used a furious comeback over the final 10 minutes to erase a 14-point second-half deficit. Cal ultimately couldn't overcome costly mistakes and poor free-throw shooting (13-for-25). "I never really felt like we had it," Benson said. "I always thought they had a chance. Since I've been here, that's the most emotionally involved I've been in a game." Midgley finished with 12 points, five rebounds and five assists, but also committed eight of Cal's 17 turnovers. Kately also had 12 points as Cal kicked off a three-game homestand with a loss. First-year UNLV coach Lon Kruger and his team began a four-game trip by playing at Cal for the first time. The Runnin' Rebels beat the Bears in the previous two meetings between the schools in Las Vegas. "We learned something tonight and picked up a win, and that's a bonus," Kruger said. "It was a good, hard-fought early season game." Cal is down to only eight healthy scholarship players after losing starting point guard Ayinde Ubaka to a broken left foot in an 82-63 win over Southern last week. He is expected to be sidelined until mid-January. Cal is already without reigning Pac-10 Freshman of the Year Leon Powe, who is expected to miss the season as he recovers from reconstructive knee surgery. UNLV's crisp ball movement led to many dunks and open jumpers in the first half, but the Runnin' Rebels made only three of their first 10 3-point tries. Michael Umeh scored seven straight points for UNLV during one first-half stretch, but Benson scored six straight points with a dunk during an 8-0 Cal run that turned a 28-21 deficit into a brief 29-28 lead. UNLV led 38-32 at halftime thanks to two late 3s by Beck. "We came back hard in the second half and staged a great comeback," Cal coach Ben Braun said. "We shot ourselves in the foot by missing some free throws."
